segments.text: You were saying about French oceanography.

I was saying about French, but you can't say anything that any particular kind of oceanography is very typical of France, because they have different groups that have different ways of doing things and different objectives.
One group is led by Jacques Cousteau.
He's primarily an engineer.
rather than a scientist.
He doesn't claim to be a scientist.

He's interested in using underwater photography and underwater vehicles and seeing what you can do with them and developing the capabilities of these devices and developing new devices, new kinds of underwater vehicles, new kinds of seeing underwater.
And, of course, they take beautiful photographs, and they've used these underwater vehicles in many interesting ways.
The bathyscape, for example.
It's the thing that they use in the submarine with this diving turtle that they use in the more shallow water.
And there's another group that works for the office organization
The French are interested in either the present French overseas possessions or former French overseas possessions like Madagascar, present French overseas possessions like New Caledonia and Tahiti.

One of my good friends, a man named Henri Roche, who works for Forrestal in New Caledonia, he has a ship which does physical and chemical and biological oceanography in the southern tropical Pacific, with headquarters in New Caledonia.
Another one was also a script of Michelle Ongo,
a station for many years in Madagascar.
And he's concerned primarily with fisheries.
They do just standard oceanography, and particularly biological oceanography, but confining themselves to mostly the waters within 1,000 miles of the place where they're stationed.
And there's a third group in the University of Paris and in the universities and other universities in France who do theoretical or quasi-theoretical oceanography.
Some of them are very good.
Particularly, they've been concerned with hydrodynamics
of the motions in the ocean, and with visible light, transmitting propagation of light in the ocean.
And they do a lot of more or less classical marine biology in the Mediterranean, and the Côte d'Ivoire, and the Bay of Biscay, and places like that.
At least there are at least three or four different kinds of oceanography done in France.
In general, it hasn't been supported very well.
They haven't done very much to bring new people into it.
It's a very small group in France.
That's in general true of the fact that oceanography is a small science.
It's generally true of

Most countries, the only countries where it's a big science, quote big science in the sense that a lot of money is spent, are the United States and the Soviet Union, and to a lesser extent, the United Kingdom and Japan.
Everywhere else, they try to do things more or less on the cheap.
And of course, most of the less developed countries have very, very limited facilities and very limited personnel.
And the result is that it's hard to do much cooperative emotionography with the less developed countries.
Now, you proposed one time that sort of an international foundation for supporting science should be established to encourage
science in underdeveloped countries.
Whatever happened to that idea?
Well, it's going.
It exists.
That was not to do with oceanography.
No.
It was to support individual science.
Right.
The headquarters of it are in Stockholm.
It's called the International Foundation for Science.
They're spending about $250,000 a year in supporting young scientists in developing countries on practical or research that looks like it had practical
would produce practical benefits.
This was proposed in Venice in 1965, if I remember correctly.
When was the foundation organized?
Well, it had its first general assembly last fall.
Oh, OK.

But it's been going now for several years, and it's building up the last year for years under the leadership of the Swedish Academy of Engineering, and with participation by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences.
It's, however, the Americans have never put any money into it, except a little bit for the Rockefeller Foundation.

The money for supporting it at the present time comes from the Swedish government, Canadian government, from Japan, and the Netherlands, and Belgium, and a little bit from other Scandinavian countries, and Germany.
And one of the things that I've got to do sometime
if I possibly can, is to try to find ways of getting American support for it, too.
They're supporting now about 50 young scientists in developing countries working on all sorts of very interesting projects that have two characteristics.
They're good science, and they also have practical objectives.
For example, one of the specialties in Scandinavia is the study of mycorrhizae.
Mycorrhizae are fungi that live on the roots of pine trees.
And in fact, a pine tree can't live without these symbiotic fungi, which absorb nutrients from the soil and transmit them to the roots.
It's a rather recent discovery that these things exist.
The recent discovery is that they're very widespread.
They've been known to exist for 75 years, I guess.
Apparently, all tropical plants require these mycorrhizae, not just the pine trees.
They act as a transmission belt for nutrients, so the nutrients are recycled in the biosphere and don't go through the soil.
Scandinavian specialty.
You might imagine that they have lots of pine trees.
And they found young scientists in Malaysia and in Nigeria and in South America and other parts of Africa and other parts of Asia, each of whom is working on mycorrhizae, the physiology,
role that they play in the symbiotic relationship of the tree and so forth.
And this has several good things about it.
One of them is that these young people have formed a network of their own.
They're communicating with each other from one blessed of all country to another, which they didn't even know the others existed before.
The other thing is that the Scandinavian scientists monitor this.

and go out and see them every now and then and help out with ideas and with literature and with equipment and with encouragement, feeling that they're doing something worth doing and not living in complete isolation.
So I think it's working out wonderfully well.
And the only real problem is it's on far too small a scale.
But that's a far cry from oceanography.
But in terms of oceanography, we have a very serious problem in the developing countries.
Those of us who were involved with forming the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission were partly responsible for this.
Although I'm not sure that I know what else we could have done.
The Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission was formed under the sponsorship of UNESCO about 1960, starting in 1959.
Most of the preliminary work was done by a small committee that I was chairman of, a small international committee.
That's the International Advisory Committee on Marine Sciences?
No, that was earlier.
That was 57 to 63, okay.
I think it was actually the International Advisory Committee on Marine Sciences was much older than that.
I think it was 51 or 52.
That was the UNESCO Advisory Committee.
Well, this was a special group of experts called together by UNESCO, I think 1959.
John Lyman was one of them, and Vladimir Kort was another from Russia.
I was the American representative.
We made a preliminary plan for the IOC, and the essence of our plan was that any country could join it
who wanted to do cooperative research at sea.
Well, that was a very narrow definition, unfortunately.
But it really said that those countries that could afford to do oceanographic research at sea could join it.
And that limited it basically to, it didn't really limit it,
It de facto was a club of rich countries.
Soviet Union, Germany, France, UK, Japan, United States, Canada.
Italy and Spain were members.
The Scandinavian countries were all members, including Finland.
They're not rich in the sense that they have big populations with big incomes, or big gross national products.
They have the fat on their bones.
They have high per capita income.
And they're able to devote considerable effort to science.

Whereas the poor countries, like most of the African countries, most of the South American countries, most of the Asian countries, are in such a desperate shape just keeping their people alive that they can't really, that oceanography is
It was a luxury for them.
And yet they feel that somehow the ocean belonged to the ocean.
Much of the ocean as possible should belong to them.
And this has come out very clearly in these Law of the Sea Conferences.
I don't think it's unfair to say that a great many of these
less developed countries, which has assumed not sea oceanography done off their coasts.
Because they feel that somehow this gives the rich countries an advantage in exploiting what they call their resources.
Since the law of the sea conference is run by politicians and diplomats with very little concept of what science is all about,
Science is taking a very, oceanographic science, I'm afraid, is taking a bad fall in those law of the sea negotiations.
The problem is basically this.
The less developed countries, the group of 77, and some developed countries like Canada and Australia, want what we

oceanography that's called a consent regime, which means that the coastal state must give its consent for any oceanographic research done within 200 miles or within its economic zone, wherever the economic zone will be defined.
Convenient definition is 200 miles beyond the territorial sea, which itself would extend 12 miles from shore.
About 40% of the ocean will be in somebody's economic field.
And most of the interesting phenomena on the ocean occur within this 200 mile limit.
Most of the geology, most of the geophysics, most of the currents, most of the organisms, most of the resources.
So this consent regime
which looks innocent enough, will in fact maybe destroy oceanography as we've done in the past.

We've had experience with it in the application of the Continental Shelf Convention, an international convention established in 1958 and now coming to force, which provides that the coastal state must give its consent for research
on the seabed and subsoil of the continental shelf off its coast, as far out as this continental shelf can.
And a lot of you know you'll write a letter to one of some of these countries.
You don't even reply.
And if they do reply, they very often, not uncommon, they deny consent.
So the oceanographers have proposed what we call a regime of rights and obligations.
This has slowly evolved over the past 10, 12 years.
The right is that anybody can do oceanographic research anywhere outside the territorial sea, provided he lives up to the following obligations.
One, prompt notification of the coastal state if you want to do the research there.
Second, coastal states will have the right of full participation in the research at sea.
In other words, send one or more people on board the ship.
We'll have complete access to everything on the ship.
One of the reasons for this is to avoid another Phoenix incident.
In other words, to ensure that these ships are not used for espionage.
Third, the right of the Coastal State, an obligation on the part of the researching state,
is to share all data and samples, give copies of all the data to the coastal state and parts of all samples.
The fourth right, or the fourth duty, is prompt publication in the open scientific literature of the results.
Fifth, or sixth, I forgot how many numbers I have.
the duty on the part of the researching state to help the coastal state in interpreting the results.
Because the coastal states say, well, what good are all these data to us if we don't have the scientists to understand what they mean?
And that's a legitimate complaint.
And finally, we have not been very enthusiastic about this, but we've agreed, I think, that the coastal state also has the right to object.
And if it does object and it has valid grounds for objection, the research will not be done.
The decision as to whether the grounds for objection are valid would be subject to arbitration.
perhaps by a group of experts appointed by UNESCO, by the IOC, the Governmental Oceanographic Commission, or in some other way, to get to be negotiated.
And it seems to us oceanographers that this set of rights and obligations protects all the interests of the coastal state.
There have been various alterations of this
the most plausible and yet the most difficult to use operationally would be that research related to the resources would be subject to consent of the coastal state.
Research related to fundamental science would be done on this more freer basis.
The trouble is, how do you define research related to resources, or how do you define fundamental research?
Oceanographers have tried to define it by saying that it shall be published in the open scientific literature.
It will not be proprietary in any way.
Many of the coastal states of the Middle East and other countries don't want that.
They want to keep the information private about the waters off their coast.

And they object, among other reasons, because, well, they have all sorts of objections, but a reason which would have seemed logical to some of our people a few years ago is that if you find out about
waters within 200 miles of the coastline, you get useful military information.
For example, how a submarine can glide, or how effectively a sonar gear will operate, and things like that.
And I guess that it's not unlikely that this consent regime will be the proof
will be the one that's approved by the Law of the Sea Conference.
If so, I think it would be better not to have any convention at all, any treaty at all.
Because this will, as far as the ocean research is concerned, it will be a very serious setback to it.
One of the things that's been put in lately, and it's called a single negotiating text, is that the coastal states shall have the right to disallow, prohibit, or prevent publication of the results.
You just can't get scientists to work unless they can publish the results of what they do.
So all in all, it will be very damaging.
And what it'll do is tend to turn oceanography
towards local problems and towards experimental and theoretical science rather than descriptive science or international ocean science.
in the sense that the whole ocean is studied, were his last words.
We would have done better if we'd paid more attention to the less developed countries in the early days of the IOC.
And the IOC has continually given sort of lip service to helping the less developed countries.
But nobody's ever known quite what to do.
It's hard to help them in ocean science because it's way down their list of priorities.
And as I say, most of the politicians in these countries feel that science is a rich man's weapon or a rich man's tool.
Therefore, some of you doesn't serve their interests.
Have you noticed much conflict between the developed countries in terms of defense industry and oceanographic science?
What do you mean by that?
Well, do you think that possibly the concepts of defense and protection interfere with international cooperation, let's say, between the Soviet Union, ourselves, Australia, Japan, for example?
Well, they certainly interfere in some aspects of international cooperation with the Soviets.
The Soviets have always taken a dim view of anybody getting too close to their shores.
And for example, in the Arctic, our people pretty much stay out of the Soviet sector of the Arctic.
And they pretty much stay out of ours.
nowhere near as much as we stay out of there.
I don't think that, in general, it's a very serious matter for most of the rich countries.
It's a serious matter with the poor countries.
For example, with all of South America.
with India, very serious with India.
Now, if you asked me earlier on what was the necessity or the virtue of the benefits of international cooperation, the benefits come mostly
in studying the large-scale oceanographic phenomena, like the Kuroshio, the Gulf Stream, or the Somali Current, or the equatorial current system.
Or problems that require, in general, problems that require the operation
several ships at the same time and in a coordinated way.

For example, some of the work that's being done under the Global Atmospheric Research Program, the GATE experiment in the Atlantic, the work that's being done on a network of buoys fairly close together.
a couple hundred miles, covering an area a few hundred miles on the side, which has a special name.
I don't remember the name right now.
Work like that, where oceanographers of several countries want to work together to study a phenomenon that they can't really study
with the resources available to any one institution.
Certainly, it's a good reason for international cooperation.
It doesn't have to be worldwide cooperation.
It could be cooperation bilateral between the United States and the United Kingdom, for example.
I think one of the most successful examples of international cooperation is the deep sea drilling program.
which is now actually being supported financially by six countries.
Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, Germany.
I guess it's five countries.
Soviet Union, United Kingdom, Germany, United States, and Japan.
And the Soviet Union putting a million dollars a year into it for the English.
And this is probably the most productive work in geophysics ever done.
It's fantastically productive of new knowledge and new results.
As you probably know, it has an elaborate advisory structure
under something called JOIDES, Joint Ocean Institutions, Deep Sea Explorations, Exploratory Studies, or something like that.
The Deep, Joint Oceanographic Institutions.
I forgot what DES stands for there.
But Woods Hole, Lamont, Scripps, University of Washington, Texas A&M, Miami,
I think Rhode Island and all these foreign countries are in it.
They plan these things cooperatively and with a great deal of success.
And scientists from all these different countries take part in expeditions.
And each leg of the program, there's a different chief scientist from a different institution, maybe French or German or British or Japanese or American or Russian.
And the participants are from a variety of countries.
This program is managed by the Scripps Institution, and we have a special
of Scripps that runs the drilling.
And it's a very expensive operation.
